content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. There are approximately six discrete, basophilic (dark purple) nodules of varying sizes, which are morphologically consistent with lymph nodes. These are embedded within pinkish fibroadipose (fatty and connective) tissue. The overall impression is a slide prepared for lymph node staging in a colorectal cancer case.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the primary task for this slide is to identify metastatic disease in the lymph nodes. Therefore, I would systematically examine each of the purple nodules. The green box highlights one of these potential lymph nodes (the one on the far left). Zooming in is essential to assess the cytoarchitectural features at high magnification to look for clusters of malignant epithelial cells, which would confirm metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When staging a colorectal cancer, it is critical to examine every lymph node submitted to determine if the cancer has spread. This process is called N staging. The area indicated by the green box is one of the potential lymph nodes on the slide (the one in the lower-left quadrant). I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic, comprehensive review of all tissue fragments to meticulously search for metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each potential lymph node on the slide. This particular area, the central and somewhat elongated basophilic structure, is one of those candidate lymph nodes. At low power, its architecture appears somewhat disrupted, with paler pink areas interspersed within the dense purple lymphoid tissue. This heterogeneity is suspicious for infiltration by tumor cells, which would disrupt the normal lymphoid pattern, prompting a closer look at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to find any potential lymph node metastasis. I would systematically examine every tissue fragment that resembles a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is a well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule, which is a classic low-power appearance of a lymph node. I am zooming into this area, which is the lymph node on the lower right, to assess its architecture and cellular components at high magnification to look for the presence of atypical epithelial cells (cancer cells) which would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the workflow for assessing a lymph node dissection in a cancer case involves a systematic, one-by-one examination of every potential lymph node identified at low power. The highlighted area clearly contains one of these lymph node candidates, located in the upper right quadrant of the slide. Zooming in is the necessary next step to assess its architecture and cellular composition to determine if it is benign (e.g., reactive) or contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area shows a well-circumscribed lymph node. The nodal architecture is preserved, with a dense population of lymphocytes. I can distinguish cortical and paracortical areas. The cells are predominantly small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no atypical glandular structures, clusters of pleomorphic cells, or other features to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a well-circumscribed lymph node surrounded by mature adipose tissue. The node is composed of a dense, uniform population of small lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would indicate metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the lymph node parenchyma is extensively infiltrated by malignant glandular structures. I see back-to-back and cribriform glands composed of atypical epithelial cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. These malignant glands are admixed with the resident lymphoid population. The findings are unequivocal for metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive (metastatic) lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes, which are the normal cells of a lymph node. The overall architecture of the lymph node appears to be preserved, with discernible lymphoid follicles. I can also see surrounding adipose tissue (fat cells) on the left. I do not see any atypical glands, nests of large cells with prominent nucleoli, or significant necrosis that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms this is a lymph node surrounded by adipose tissue. The node's architecture is characterized by dense sheets and follicles composed of small, dark lymphocytes. I see multiple lymphoid follicles, some with apparent germinal centers, and a large confluent area of lymphocytes. This pattern is characteristic of a reactive lymph node, likely showing follicular hyperplasia. I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as infiltrating malignant glands, large pleomorphic cells with vesicular nuclei, or prominent nucleoli. Therefore, my initial impression of this specific lymph node is that it is negative for metastasis and shows reactive changes.
